text: Hi. I was trying to make a custom distribution for Turing to help avoid loops, and to make certain common operations easier. I have to define a bijector for the distribution. My distribution is a Continuous matrix-variate, so it should be an identity bijector, but I see things like Identity{0}, Identity{1}, etc. What does that number refer to? The dimensionality of the transformation? Something else?

elements.text: Hi. I was trying to make a custom distribution for Turing to help avoid loops, and to make certain common operations easier. I have to define a bijector for the distribution. My distribution is a Continuous matrix-variate, so it should be an identity bijector, but I see things like Identity{0}, Identity{1}, etc. What does that number refer to? The dimensionality of the transformation? Something else?

text: I could try a few values and see what works, but I'm curious to know when to choose one option over another.

elements.text: I could try a few values and see what works, but I'm curious to know when to choose one option over another.

text: It's the dimensionality, so you want `Identity{2}`. It's an unfortunate necessity to ensure that we can support stuff like batched transformations

. It's an unfortunate necessity to ensure that we can support stuff like batched transformations
